repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Judicial Reform Project; Third
            Structural Adjustment Credit Project; Reform Support Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Judicial Reform Project
            for Georgia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            negligible, Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Ratings for the Third Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC3)
            Project for Georgia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was high, Bank performance was unsatisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was also unsatisfactory. Ratings for the Reform
            Support Credit Project for Georgia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was satisfactory, and
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the experience of the Judicial Reform
            Project shows that making the judiciary more independent,
            effective, adherent to higher ethical standards and
            professional requires interventions that go beyond
            rehabilitating infrastructure, using information technology,
            and educating the public. Establishment of an independent
            and effective judiciary requires strong political will and
            continuous commitment of the country authorities, which a
            Bank operation can only complement, but not substitute for.
            The experience of SAC3 and Reform Support Credits reiterates
            that Bank support can be effective in promoting and
            supporting change when the authorities are ready for reform,
            but not otherwise. When the authorities are not ready it
            could be argued that financial support may weaken the need
            for change and strengthen the capacity to maintain the
            status quo The experience of the Reform Support Credit shows
            that simpler rules reduce opportunities for corruption. When
            the government simplified the rules and streamlined
            administrative procedures in organizations like the traffic
            police, customs, and tax administration their staff
            delivered better services and extorted fewer bribes.

10247713.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rule of law,Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            substantial. Lessons drawn from the project suggest the
            following. The components of this operation emerged from
            within the Government's overall development strategy,
            which created ownership, and in turn recognized the extent
            of policymakers' consensus to prod the reform agenda.
            Moreover, participation of the civil society and the overall
            level of public trust is an important element for
            introducing radical reforms, and successful implementation
            of its process. Moreover, a clear and well defined
            assignment of responsibility within government entities
            specified and defined the boundaries of responsibility, and
            accountability for the implementation of various parts of
            the reform process. This further supported the achievement
            of program objectives, through a well coordinated effort
            among donors, both in terms of advice and activities so as
            to maximize synergies and improve cohesiveness. The
            importance of Government institutional and implementation
            capacity is emphasized, as a binding constraint for
            successful development, and implementation of each component
            of a reform program, and key to ensure sustainability of reforms

abstracts.cdata!:
The Reform Support Credit Project aims
            to provide initial assistance to the new Government of
            Georgia, in its efforts to define, and implement a program
            of economic, legal, and social reforms. The Project will
            support actions in the following areas: 1) improvement in
            governance and anti-corruption; 2) improvement in public
            finance management; and, 3) steps to resolve crucial issues
            in the energy sector. Actions taken in these areas will
            significantly contribute to the implementation of broader
            structural reforms over the medium term. At the same time,
            the project aims to define, in broad preliminary terms, a
            framework for future policy-based lending, and policy
            dialogue by the International Development Association (IDA),
            to support the country's medium-term economic growth,
            and poverty reduction efforts. This will further support
            fiscal stability and poverty reduction directly. First, the
            proposed project will address issues of governance,
            corruption, and the business environment, to facilitate new
            businesses, and create employment. Second, a stable fiscal
            environment should allow for the timely payment of salaries,
            pensions, and social expenditures. It will also foster
            Government links between the Economic Development and
            Poverty Reduction Framework programs and the budget process.
            Despite risks, the new political environment, the
            overwhelming electoral victories at the Presidential and
            Parliamentary elections, and the recent return of Adjara
            under the authority of the Government, will help ameliorate
            these risks, while lessons of past adjustment lending, in
            particular the weak government implementation capacity, have
            been carefully factored into the design: a narrow focus on
            priority issues, and the requirement for reform implementation.
